questions.text: Which is true about BP measurement?

options.label: A
options.text: Korotkoff sound 4 corresponds to intra-arterial diastolic blood pressure

options.label: B
options.text: BP cuff should be 40% of arm circumference

options.label: C
options.text: Small cuffs give rise to spuriously high BP recordings

options.label: D
options.text: Monkeberg sclerosis gives rise to spuriously high BP recordings

questions.correct_answer: B. BP cuff should be 40% of arm circumference
questions.explanation:
Solution:

BP cuff should be 40% of arm circumference The width of the cuff should be 40% greater than the patient arm (not 40% of the arm) and should cover 80% of the length of the arm.

Highyeild:

Usually, the width of the cuff is: 12-15 cm for adults 6-9 cm for children 5 cm for neonates.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- The Auscultation method depends on the auscultation of korotkoff sounds during the deflation of the The first sound (phase I) is taken as Systolic BP while the last sound (phase IV or V) is accepted as diastolic BP. Option C - Too large cuff will underestimate while too small cuff will overestimate the actual value. Loose cuffs also overestimate the actual value. Option D- Patients with arteriosclerosis have less compressible arteries therefore will overestimate the actual blood pressure. Similarly decreased compliance of the tissues under the cuff (for example in shivering) requires high cuff occluding pressure overestimating the actual value.

Extraedge:

One important source of error is the rapid deflation of the The deflation rate should be 3-5 mmHg/sec Due to the widespread availability of automatic blood pressure measurement devices, blood pressure by auscultation is rarely employed during monitoring in anesthesia.

questions.text: Automatic sphygmomanometer directly measures:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mean arterial pressure (MAP) Automated NIBP devices measures MAP by oscillometry. The peak of oscillation represents mean arterial pressure.

Highyeild:

In the auscultation method, systolic and diastolic BP are measured while MAP is calculated by the formula

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- SBP is derived by set algorithms from mean arterial pressure Option B- Like SBP, DBP is also derived by set algorithms from MAP.

Extraedge:

Automatic BP devices measure BP automatically after a set interval. The interval between 2 BP recordings should not be > 5 minutes.

questions.text: Blood pressure during anesthesia is monitored by cannulating:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Radial artery As the Radial artery has collateral circulation through the transpalmar arch it is most commonly cannulated for continuous blood pressure monitoring.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Because of increased chances of infection and non-availability of collaterals, the femoral is generally not preferred. Option B- Distal arteries could have significant disparity due to the gravity effect, therefore, are not preferred. Moreover, the temporal artery has a tortuous course making cannulation to become difficult. Option D- Ulnar can be used as an alternative to radial artery but generally not preferred because of its deep location and torturous course.

Extraedge:

As invasive blood pressure is the method of continuously measuring BP, it is considered a gold standard method for BP monitoring

questions.text: An 80-year-old male with a known case of CKD and aortic stenosis is undergoing emergency laparotomy. Anesthetist wants to do invasive BP monitoring on this patient. Before cannulating the radial artery, he would like to do which test?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Modified Allen’s test Modified Allen’s test is done to determine the presence of collateral circulation (transpalmar arch) of the hand /patency of the ulnar artery before cannulating the radial artery.

Highyeild:

Modified Allen’s test involves testing one hand at a time. After exsanguination of the hand, pressure is applied on the radial and ulnar artery till the hand is blanched from pressure. Now release the ulnar artery while still maintaining pressure on the radial artery. If the ulnar artery is patent, the normal color of the hand should return within 6-10 seconds. This is considered as a positive modified Allen’s test. If the color does not return in 10 seconds test is considered negative which means ulnar circulation is compromised and we should not cannulate the radial artery

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Kety Schmidt test is done to check cerebral blood flow Option B- In the original Allen’s test patient’s both hands are compared by occluding the radial artery of the hand to be cannulated. If the color of the hand remains the same that means Ulnar circulation is patent. If there is discoloration that means ulnar circulation is compromised. This is called a positive Allen’s test. So, a positive Allen’s test means that we should avoid cannulating the radial artery. Option D- There is no Swan Ganz test, it's only the Swan Ganz catheter which is used for pulmonary artery catheterization

Extraedge:

Reverse Allen’s test is done to see the patency of the radial artery during ulnar artery cannulation. In this test, pressure is maintained on the Ulnar artery while it is released from the radial artery. Normal return of color in 6-10 seconds indicates the patency of the radial artery

questions.text: The best reference point for zeroing off the transducer for invasive BP monitoring:

options.label: A
options.text: At the level of the sternum

options.label: B
options.text: 3 cm posterior to the sternal border

options.label: C
options.text: 5 cm posterior to the sternal border

questions.correct_answer: C. 5 cm posterior to the sternal border
questions.explanation:
Solution:

5 cm posterior to the sternal border For Invasive BP monitoring, the best position at which the transducer is transduced is 5 cm posterior to the sternal border which corresponds to the aortic root level

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- If transduced at the sternal level, it will be anterior to the heart giving false values Option B- 3 cm posterior to the sternal border does not correspond to the aortic root level Option D- CVP catheters should be zeroed at the mid-axillary line which represents the right atrium

Extraedge:

Previously (and still in many centers) arterial transducers were also leveled at the mid-axillary line

questions.text: A patient in ICU is being cannulated through a radial artery for direct arterial pressure monitoring. After some time, the patient developed the paleness of the involved hand. The definitive management will be:

options.label: B
options.text: IV local anesthesia through the same line

options.label: D
options.text: Remove the needle and massage the hand

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stellate ganglion block The paleness of the hand indicates that the radial artery has gone into spasm and moreover collaterals (ulnar artery) are also not adequately functioning. Definitive management to relieve this vasospasm would be stellate ganglion block.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Local application of thrombophob gel is done for thrombophlebitis Option C- IV local anesthetic should be given instantly to relieve vasospasm however is not the definitive management Option D- Local massaging is not going to help at all

questions.text: All of the following are the uses of Central venous catheterization except:

options.label: B
options.text: For Pulmonary artery catheterization and monitoring

questions.explanation:
Solution:

None of the above Central venous catheterization is mainly done for Central venous pressure monitoring.

Highyeild:

Other uses are: Placement of Pulmonary artery catheters Transvenous cardiac pacing Drug administration Fluid administration Hyperalimentation Aspiration of air emboli For taking blood samples

questions.text: A 37-year-old patient with RTA is admitted to ICU. As the patient is on ionotropic support it was decided to cannulate one of the central veins for CVP monitoring and to inject inotrope. The vein most often chosen for central venous pressure monitoring is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Right internal jugular Although there is no ideal vein however Right internal jugular is most often cannulated for CVP monitoring because it is valveless, is a direct continuation to the heart, and is overall best in logistics and complications.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- Left internal jugular is less preferred because of its indirect course to reach the right atrium increasing the chances of malposition Option C- Subclavian is less preferred over internal jugular because of increased chances of mechanical complications particularly pneumothorax Option D- Very long catheters are needed to reach the right atrium through the antecubital making CVP to become inaccurate

questions.text: Untrue about CVP monitoring:

options.label: A
options.text: Seldinger technique is utilized for cannulation

options.label: B
options.text: Tip of the catheter should lie in the right atrium

options.label: D
options.text: During catheterization direction of needle should be towards ipsilateral nipple

questions.correct_answer: B. Tip of the catheter should lie in the right atrium
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tip of the catheter should lie in the right atrium The tip should lie at the junction of the superior vena cava with the right atrium, never in the cardiac chamber

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- CVP catheterization is done through the Seldinger technique in which the catheter is threaded over a J wire. Option C- Normal CVP is 3-10 cmH2O Option D- The point of insertion is at the cricoid level and the guide to direction is the ipsilateral nipple.

questions.text: A 60-year male with chronic obstructive lung disease is admitted to ICU with a pulse of 120/min and BP of 80/60 mmHg. On the right internal jugular cannulation, CVP recorded is 2 cmH2O. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypovolemia Normal CVP is 3 to 10 cm of H2O (or 2-8 mmHg). A low CVP with low BP indicates hypovolemia while a high CVP with low BP indicates pump failure.

Highyeild:

CVP is increased in Fluid overloading. Congestive cardiac failure. Right ventricular ischemia Tricuspid stenosis and regurgitation Cardiac tamponade and constrictive pericarditis Intermittent positive pressure ventilation with PEEP. Pulmonary embolism. Pleural effusion. Hemothorax. Coughing and straining. CVP is decreased in Hypovolemia and shock. Venodilators. Spinal/epidural General anesthetics (by causing vasodilatation).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B, and C- So, in congestive cardiac failure, pulmonary embolism, and pleural effusion BP will be low while CVP will be high

questions.text: The most common acute complication of CVP catheterization:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Arterial puncture Arterial puncture is considered as the most common acute complication of CVP catheterization.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- Pneumothorax is a dangerous complication, more commonly seen after the subclavian route however it is not the most common Option C- Cardiac tamponade is one of the most dreadful complications of central venous catheterization but fortunately it's very rare. It occurs if the catheter punctures the wall of the right atrium and then the fluid is given through the same catheter. Option D- Brachial plexus injury has also been reported; mainly after subclavian catheterization but again it's very rare.

Extraedge:

Central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSI) are considered as a most common late complication of CVP catheterization

questions.text: In a patient CVP and intra-arterial pressure were monitored. During the monitoring, the patient suddenly developed supraventricular tachycardia. Changes seen in the pressure reading are:
questions.correct_answer: A. Increased CVP and decreased BP
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased CVP and decreased BP Any arrhythmia can occur during CVP catheterization. In supraventricular tachycardia, the atrial filling is compromised leading to decreased venous return thereby increasing the CVP. PSVT can sometimes cause life-threatening hypotension.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- increased CVP and BP may be seen in fluid overloading or during the use of vasopressors Option C- Decreased CVP and increased BP are rare but may occur in the early phase of shock where selective intense vasoconstriction in arterial circulation can increase BP Option D- Decrease CVP along with hypotension is typical of hypovolemia

questions.text: A patient with a history of myocardial ischemia was operated on for cholecystectomy. In the post-operative period he developed severe respiratory distress. Pulmonary artery catheterization was done which shows a value of 28 mmHg. The likely diagnosis is:

options.label: B
options.text: Pneumothorax due to rupture of pleura during surgery

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cardiac asthma Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure indicates the pressure of the left atrium. Normal PCWP is 4-12 mmHg. Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of more than 25 mmHg indicates pulmonary edema i.e., cardiac asthma.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C- Hemothorax, pneumothorax if significant, may impede the venous return, decreasing the preload to the left heart, and decreasing PAOP Option D- PAOP is usually not affected by asthma

Extraedge:

Pulmonary artery occlusion pressure (PAOP) is the newer term for PCWP.

questions.text: While introducing the Swan-Ganz catheter, its placement in the pulmonary artery can be identified by the following pressure tracing:

options.label: A
options.text: Diastolic pressure is lower in PA than in RV

options.label: B
options.text: Diastolic pressure is higher in PA than in RV

options.label: C
options.text: PA pressure tracing has a dicrotic notch from the closure of the pulmonary valve

options.label: D
options.text: RV pressure tracing shows a sharp drop in early diastole

questions.correct_answer: B. Diastolic pressure is higher in PA than in RV
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diastolic pressure is higher in PA than in RV Swan Ganz catheter is used for pulmonary artery catheterization. It is balloon-tipped and flow-directed (which means moves along with the blood flow in cardiac chambers). The presence of the catheter in a different part of the heart is guided by pressure recordings, pressure tracings, and distance from the catheter tip A sudden increase in diastolic pressure at a distance of 35-45 cm confirms the position of the Swan Ganz catheter in the pulmonary artery (diastolic pressure in the right ventricle is 0 to 8 mmHg while in the pulmonary artery it is 5 to 15 mmHg).

Highyeild:

At 15 cm, the tip should be in the right atrium which is confirmed by pressure recordings and tracings on the The sudden increase in systolic pressure at a distance of 20-25cm indicates the presence of the catheter in the right ventricle (systolic pressure in the Right atrium is 0 to 8 mmHg while in the Right ventricle it is 15 to 30 mmHg). The difference in pressure tracings may also be helpful in determining the presence of a catheter in the right atrium vs. right ventricle or pulmonary artery vs. the branch of the pulmonary artery but of no use in the right ventricle vs. pulmonary artery because pressure tracing of both are almost similar with very minor differences which are too difficult to observe on running monitor.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Diastolic pressure is higher in the pulmonary artery than the right ventricle Option C- PA pressure has a dicrotic notch, however, it is difficult to see on a running monitor therefore cannot be used as a confirmatory method Option D- There is no sharp drop, moreover it is difficult to demarcate subtle waveform changes.

Extraedge:

Pulmonary capillary wedge is better known as pulmonary artery occlusion pressure

questions.text: Best lead to detect ischemia during anesthesia:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lead V3 Recent studies have found V3 or V4 to be more sensitive than V5 for detection arrhythmias

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Lead II is best to detect arrhythmias not ischemia Option B- V1 detects RV ischemia while ischemia is far more common in LV Option D- Historically lead V5 had been considered to be the most sensitive to detect myocardial ischemia

questions.text: The most sensitive and practical technique for the detection of myocardial ischemia in the perioperative period is:

options.label: C
options.text: Regional wall motion abnormality detected with the help of 2D trans-esophageal echocardiography

questions.correct_answer: C. Regional wall motion abnormality detected with the help of 2D trans-esophageal echocardiography
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Regional wall motion abnormality detected with the help of 2D trans-esophageal echocardiography Trans-esophageal echocardiography (TEE) is an excellent and simple semi-invasive method in which a probe is placed in an esophagus-like gastroscope during GA. It is far more sensitive than ECG to detect any wall motion abnormality i.e., ischemia, however, its specificity is low.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- MR spectroscopy is neither sensitive nor practically possible in the perioperative period Option B- For direct measurement of pressures cardiac catheterization is required which is highly invasive and associated with life-threatening complications Option D- 12 lead ECG is neither practically possible in the perioperative period nor as sensitive as TEE.

Extraedge:

The limitation of TEE is that it can be utilized only in patients in GA

questions.text: All of the following are the limitations of the following equipment except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyperbilirubinemia Hyperbilirubinemia generally has no direct effect unless it is severe (> 30 mg%)

Highyeild:

Limitation/Errors in pulse oximeter: Abnormal hemoglobins: Cannot detect abnormal Hb like Carboxyhaemoglobin, Methemoglobin, or Sulphhemoglobin. However, they perform accurately in the presence of sickle and fetal Hemoglobin. Anemia: Severe anemia causes underestimation of actual values. Hypovolemia and vasoconstriction (especially in cold): Difficulty in obtaining actual values. Vasodilatation: Slight decrease. Nail polish (especially blue color) or Henna: Impairs the transmission of light and therefore shows false reading. Shivering: Constant movement of finger impairs the continuous transmission of light and hence false reading. SpO2 below 60%: Below 60% most instruments underestimate the actual value. Skin pigmentation: Dark pigmentation can impair the transmission of light Dyes like methylene blue or indocyanine green.

questions.text: A gold standard non-invasive method for measurement of arterial oxygen saturation:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Co-oximeter Co-oximeter is the special oximeters that can measure the concentration of all 5 species of Hb i.e., oxyHb, DeoxyHb, COHb, MethHb, and SulphHb while normal pulse oximeters measure only oxy and DeoxyHb. That is why co-oximeters are considered as the gold standard method for the measurement of arterial oxygen saturation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Pulse oximeters cannot detect abnormal Hb therefore in the presence of abnormal Hb, they give false values. For example, Methemoglobinemia shows a fix saturation of 85% irrespective of actual value. Carboxyhaemoglobinemia shows higher than the actual value. Option C- Newer advanced blood gas machines can measure abnormal Hb however blood gasses is an invasive method Option D- Capnograph measures expired CO2

Extraedge:

Multiwavelength pulse oximeters are being manufactured nowadays which like co-oximeters can detect abnormal hemoglobin

questions.text: Pulse oximeters uses two lights of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

660 nm and 940 nm Pulse oximeters work on the principle of Beer-Lambert It states that different solvents absorb infrared (and red light) at different wavelengths. A pulse oximeter probe emits two lights of different wavelengths; red at 660nm and infrared at 940nm. Oxyhemoglobin absorbs more infrared light while deoxyhemoglobin absorbs more red light. This ratio of red to infrared light is measured and converted in numerical value by a processor in a pulse oximeter.

questions.text: Best site to take a sample for mixed venous saturation (SVO2):
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pulmonary artery Mixed venous oxygen saturation is considered as the best parameter to assess overall tissue perfusion. The normal value is 65-80%. As the pulmonary artery had blood mixed from all parts of the body, it is considered the best site for taking a sample for SVO2 however practically it is most often taken from the central line (superior vena cava)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Basilic vein does not represent global oxygen (total body oxygen), it represents only regional oxygen. Option B- Subclavian vein also does not represent global oxygen (total body oxygen), it represents oxygen from one side only Option C- Due to difficulty in assessing the pulmonary artery, the superior vena cava is considered a surrogate however it represents blood only from the upper part of the body.

Extraedge:

Urine out is the best clinical parameter to assess tissue perfusion (cardiac output)

questions.text: A young patient met an RTA and came to an accident and emergency in a shocked state with PR- 120/mt and BP- 70/40 mmHg. Due to massive injury on both upper limbs, the right subclavian vein was canulated for resuscitation. Blood was taken from the subclavian vein to do the venous blood gas analysis. Oxygen saturation in this sample would be:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Less In conditions like respiratory diseases, and hypovolemic or cardiogenic shock, tissue uptake is normal but oxygen delivery is impaired. Therefore, oxygen content and saturation of venous blood will be low.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- In conditions like cyanide poisoning, advanced stages of septic shock, and Histotoxic hypoxia, oxygen delivery to tissues is normal but uptake by tissues is impaired so unutilized oxygen reaches the venous side increasing the oxygen content (and saturation) of venous blood. Option C- Mixed venous oxygen saturation will be reduced shock Option D- It may be high only in septic shock or prolonged shock which has produced cell damage

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cardiovascular monitoring technique?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Capnography Capnography which is the measurement of end-tidal carbon dioxide is a respiratory monitor.

Highyeild:

The normal value is 32-42 mmHg (3-4 mmHg less than PCO2). It is a very sensitive respiratory monitor to give an analysis of each breath.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B, and C – TEE, CVP monitoring, and Pulmonary artery catheterization are cardiovascular monitoring techniques

questions.text: The instrument marked with an arrow is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mainstream Capnometer This is a mainstream capnometer where a CO2 measuring head (marked with an arrow) is placed at the end of the breathing circuit, i.e., between the breathing circuit and the artificial airway. The capnograph head acts as a sampling as well as an analysis chamber; Infrared light is delivered through side windows. CO2 is analyzed there and thence only.

Highyeild:

Advantages of mainstream capnometer: The major advantage is fast response, sampling errors caused by suction pump or water vapor in the tubing can be avoided. Disadvantages of mainstream capnometer: Increases dead space, vulnerable to damage by external factors, sensor window must remain clear and they must be heated to 40C to avoid water condensation. This increase in temperature can affect the results and increase the risk of burns

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- In the sidestream capnometer a gas sample is taken from the circuit, and delivered to monitor through sampling tubes where it is analyzed and displayed. Advantages: It does not increase the dead space; the sensor is not vulnerable to damage by external factors. Disadvantages: Delay response time, and water vapor in the tubing can significantly alter the results. Option C- Oxygen analyzers are the devices placed on the inspiratory side of the circuit to tell the final delivered concentration of oxygen to the patient Option D- Temperature analyzer is just a probe (like 6 no, Ryles tubes) which can be placed in the esophagus to measure core temperature

Extraedge:

Nowadays, most modern machines are using side stream capnometers

questions.text: What does point D represent in the following image?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

End-Tidal point Normal capnography waveform has four phases: Phase I: contains dead space gases with almost no CO2 Phase II: Transition from phase I (dead space) to phase III (alveolar phase) Phase III: Alveolar phase Phase IV: Downslope at the time of inspiration Therefore, in the above diagram point, A to D represents expiration while D to E is the inspiration

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- Inspiratory phase is D-E Option C- Dead space gases phase in A-B Option D- Alveolar phase in C-D

questions.text: The following ETCO2 curve depicts:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Spontaneous efforts This graph is depicting the spontaneous effort of the patient during control breathing.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- Bronchospasm presents at prolonged phase 2 of graph Option C- esophageal intubation will present as a flat line on capnography Option D- Successful resuscitation is represented by a normal capnograph

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was undergoing tonsillectomy under GA with O2+N2O+ sevoflurane + cis-atracurium. During surgery, the anesthetist notices the following graph. What intervention should be done after seeing this graph?

options.label: A
options.text: Repeat the dose of muscle relaxant

options.label: C
options.text: Rapid infusion of 200 ml of ringer lactate

questions.correct_answer: C. Rapid infusion of 200 ml of ringer lactate
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rapid infusion of 200 ml of ringer lactate Spontaneous effort as shown in this graph is represented by a curare notch which indicates that the effect of muscle relaxant is waning off and the dose should be repeated.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- If the anesthetic depth is inadequate, we need to increase the dose of sevoflurane: capnography cannot determine the depth of anesthesia Option C- Hypotension can decrease the perfusion decreasing the CO2, not producing the curare notch Option D- Increased oxygen concentration is required in case of hypoxia which is detected by the pulse oximeter.

questions.text: The following capnogram represents:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endobronchial intubation Bifid pattern in capnogram indicates endobronchial intubation

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Defective exhalation valve of a closed circuit and exhausted soda lime will lead to CO2 entering the inspiratory limb preventing CO2 levels to reach baseline producing the following graph Option B- Bronchospasm produces prolonged expiratory phase (II and III) producing shark fin pattern of the graph as seen in the following diagram Option C- Spontaneous effort of the patient produces the following graph

questions.text: A young 20-year-old patient is undergoing humerus plating under GA. The anesthetist notices the following graph of capnography. All of the following conditions may produce this trace except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cardiac oscillations Cardiac oscillations are reflected by simple oscillations of cardiac activity reflected on a normal capnograph in the diagram shown below. Cardiac oscillations are seen in very lean and thin patients

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B, and C- CO2 suddenly becoming zero and graph becoming flatline is seen in Esophageal intubation, Accidental extubation, Complete obstruction, Disconnection, Ventilation failure, Cardiac arrest (there is no blood to carry CO2 from tissues to lungs)

questions.text: ETCO2 immediately becoming zero is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Accidental extubation Capnography is the surest method to confirm intubation. In case of accidental extubation, it will immediately become zero and the graph will become flatline

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- In cardiac arrest, it also becomes zero because there is no blood to carry CO2 from tissues to lungs however it will become zero after a few waveforms (CO2 present in lungs keep on exhaling for few breaths before becoming zero) Option C- In malignant hyperthermia CO2 production increases so rapidly that it can cross even 80-90 mmHg Option D- Pulmonary embolism by air, fat, or thrombus blocks a segment from which CO2 is not exhaled decreasing ETCO2.

questions.text: During positioning of a patient who has undergone craniotomy, it is suddenly found that pO2 = 85% and end-tidal carbon dioxide becomes zero. The possible diagnosis is:

options.label: B
options.text: Blockage of the endotracheal tube by secretions

questions.correct_answer: A. Endotracheal tube in the esophagus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endotracheal tube in the esophagus End-tidal carbon dioxide is the surest sign of correct intubation. During positioning, there is a chance of accidental extubation of the tube producing a flat capnogram.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- Complete blockage of the endotracheal tube can cause ETCO2 to become zero, however, is very rare as compared to accidental extubation. Option C- End-tidal carbon dioxide may decrease in venous air embolism, even becomes zero if the embolus is large enough to block the main pulmonary circulation however, such a large embolus is very rare. Moreover, this will occur late, when the dura is opened, not during positioning. Option D- Tracheomalacia will not cause ETCO2 to become zero

questions.text: You are posted in a high dependency unit of medicine where a patient with a known case of COPD is received in a drowsy state with spo2 of 85%. ABG was performed to find his CO2 was 80 mmHg. You decided to start Bi- PAP however you found that the Bi-PAP machine was not working, therefore, you decided to start oxygen with the nasal cannula at a flow rate of 2L/ minute. As this patient is prone to go in apnea therefore apnea monitoring is a must for this patient. The best method to monitor apnea in this patient would have been:

options.label: C
options.text: Temperature of the breathed air in the nose

questions.correct_answer: A. Thoracic electrical impedance pneumography/ pulmometry
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thoracic electrical impedance pneumography/ pulmometry Thoracic electrical impedance pneumography/ pulmometry is a very simple method to monitor in a non-intubated patient. A low amplitude current is delivered through ECG electrodes by ECG cables. The change in lung volume changes the resistance to this current which is detected by software to calculate tidal volume and respiratory rate. Majority of the newer monitors are using this method to detect apnea in non-intubated patients.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- Capnography is an excellent monitor to detect apnea in non-intubated patient Option C- The temperature of breathed air can be used as a signal to detect apnea however has many limitations and therefore, not used Option D- Pulse oximeter may detect apnea by detecting desaturation but does not directly detect apnea; there may be other causes of desaturation too.

Extraedge:

Another commonly used method that can be used to detect apnea in non-intubated patients is nasal capnography by using nasal probes however it is very vulnerable to dilution by air or inhaled oxygen.

questions.text: The monitor shown in the following figure is used for monitoring:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Depth of anesthesia This is the Bispectral index monitor which was the first scientifically validated and commercially available monitor to check the depth of anesthesia. It analyzes multiple facets of real-time EEG to generate a score by the set algorithm.

Highyeild:

It will exhibit a score of 100 for a fully awake state and 0 for a completely silent brain. A bispectral index score (BIS) score of 45-60 indicates adequate depth.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- Muscle relaxation is measured by neuromuscular monitoring devices which most often use adductor pollicis muscle Option C- There is no monitor to measure the pain intensity. Option B- cerebral blood flow can be measured by transcranial doppler

Extraedge:

Entropy is the new monitor to measure the depth of anesthesia. The advantage of entropy over BIS is that it can identify errors due to motion artifacts

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient is undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery. Patient on bypass surgery need a reduction in the metabolic rate of the body which is achieved by inducing hypothermia. All of the following statements regarding hypothermia are true except:

options.label: A
options.text: Postanesthetic shivering increases oxygen consumption by 400%

options.label: B
options.text: Drug of choice for the treatment of shivering is pethidine

options.label: C
options.text: Hypothermia may be defined as core body temperature less than 35°C

options.label: D
options.text: With each degree fall in temperature the metabolic rate is reduced by 8%

questions.correct_answer: A. Postanesthetic shivering increases oxygen consumption by 400%
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Postanesthetic shivering increases oxygen consumption by 400% Hypothermia is compensated by shivering. Contrary to the previous belief that shivering increase O2 consumption by 4 times (400%) recent studies have found that shivering increases oxygen consumption by 100%

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B- Pethidine is the drug of choice for the treatment of shivering however other drugs like clonidine, tramadol, physostigmine, dexmedetomidine, and magnesium sulfate can also be used Option C- Hypothermia may be defined as a core body temperature less than 35°C. It is classified as mild (28°-35°C), moderate (21°-27°C), and profound (< 20°C). Option D- With each degree fall in temperature the metabolic rate is reduced by 6-8%; reducing the temperature by 10°C can reduce the metabolic rate of the body by 60- 80%

questions.text: As hypothermia is very common in the intraoperative period, temperature monitoring may be considered mandatory in most of the surgeries. Untrue about core body temperature:

questions.correct_answer: D. Core body temperature is lower than rectal temperature
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Core body temperature is lower than rectal temperature Core temperature is the most accurate method of temperature monitoring. Core temperature is higher than the rectal temperature which is higher than surface temperature.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Considering all the advantages like the economy, accuracy safety, feasibility, and accessibility lower end of the esophagus is considered as the best site for core body temperature monitoring. Option B- Although the pulmonary artery is the most accurate site for measuring core body temperature however due to cost, technical infeasibility, and risk of dangerous complication like pulmonary artery rupture, hemothorax, and arrythmias, it is not used. Option C- Both Nasopharynx and the tympanic membrane are reliable in measuring brain temperature. Although tympanic membrane is more accurate than the nasopharynx but the presence of wax alters the value and increased the chances of perforation of the tympanic membrane, the nasopharynx is more frequently used.

questions.text: Identify the nerve being tested for neuromuscular monitoring procedure:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ulnar Due to technical ease and availability of enough space to apply electrodes, adductor pollicis, supplied by the ulnar nerve is most frequently employed for neuromuscular monitoring.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C, and D - Although theoretically, any nerve muscle unit can be used for neuromuscular monitoring however other adductor pollicis ( or corrugator supercilli and orbicularis oculi) no muscle has been utilized practically

Extraedge:

As the response in corrugator supercilli, (supplied by facial nerve) corresponds with laryngeal muscles it is considered as ideal muscle for monitoring but since its monitoring is technically very difficult, therefore generally is not used.

questions.text: ‘Train of four’ is characteristically used in concern with:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers ‘Train of four’ is the most commonly used modality for neuromuscular monitoring.

Highyeild:

In the train of four stimulation four stimuli, each of 2 Hz frequencies are given and the ratio of the 4th to 1st response is recorded. The normal ratio (without muscle relaxants) is 1. With depolarizers, the amplitude of all 4 recordings decreases simultaneously while with non-depolarizers T4 decrease in proportion to T1. This is called fading. Thereafter loss of responses is called as TOF score

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- A train of four has nothing to do with malignant hyperthermia. The best test to rule out the patient’s vulnerability to malignant hyperthermia is the halothane caffeine test Option C- The efficiency of the closed circuit is checked by looking at the color of soda lime and monitoring end-tidal co2 Option D- Pulse oximeters work on the principle of Beer-Lambert law

Extraedge:

Other modalities which can be used for neuromuscular monitoring are: Single twitch Tetanic stimulation Post tetanic stimulation Double burst stimulation

questions.text: The beta waveform in EEG indicate which of the following state of anesthesia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Light anesthesia EEG, although not very reliable, but can be utilized to assess the depth of anesthesia. Beta waves (in the frontal area) indicate light anesthesia (sub-anesthetic depth). At moderate depth, beta waves are replaced by alpha waves.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Deep anesthesia causes slowing of EEG-producing delta and theta waves. Option B- Surgical anesthesia means deep anesthesia so predominating waves should be theta or delta

questions.text: Which of the following in anesthesia will produce decreased EEG activities?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypothermia Effect of anesthetic agents and modalities on EEG: All inhalational and intravenous anesthetic agents produce a biphasic pattern on EEG i.e. at lower doses they cause excitation (high frequency and low amplitude waves) followed by depression (high amplitude and low-frequency waves) at high doses with the following exceptions: Opioids only produce depression. Nitrous oxide and ketamine only produce excitation. A similar pattern has been seen with hypoxia and hypercarbia i.e. early (mild) hypoxia and hypercarbia produce excitation while late (advanced) hypoxia and hypercarbia produce a depression of EEG. Hypothermia and cerebral ischemia produce only progressive depression of EEG.

Option D- Although monitors can display airway pressure however usually airway pressures are exhibited by ventilators.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female was brought to the emergency for acute abdominal pain and shifted to OT for laparotomy. Speedy intubation was performed. On auscultation breath, sounds were found to be decreased on the left side with high ET CO2. Likely diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endobronchial intubation Decrease breath sounds on the left side means that the tube has slipped into the right bronchus. Initially, there may be low end-tidal CO2 (as CO2 is coming from the right side only) but soon left lung will start to act as a shunt (only perfusion, no ventilation) increasing arterial and hence end-tidal CO2.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A- Endotracheal tube blockage will decrease the ETCO2 Option B- ETCO2 remains normal in bronchospasm Option C- ETCO2 will become zero in esophageal intubation

questions.text: A 40-year-old female was undergoing abdominal surgery. Postoperatively she said that she was aware of perioperative events. Which method should have been used that would be helpful to avoid intraoperative awareness? Pulse oximetry Clinical signs of sympathetic stimulation Bispectral index Entropy Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2, 3, and 4 are correct Until very recently depth of anesthesia was mainly monitored by clinical signs which include: Signs of sympathetic stimulation like hypertension, tachycardia, lacrimation, perspiration, and mydriasis. Movement response to painful stimuli, and eye movements but may not be seen in patients who have been given muscle relaxants. Tachypnea, laryngospasm, bronchospasm or breath holding. EEG and evoked responses were also utilized to assess depth of anesthesia but were very difficult to monitor and not too reliable either. BispectRal index SCORE (BIS) is the first scientifically validated and commercially available monitor to check the depth of anesthesia. It utilizes many parameters like multiple EEG signals to calculate a score. A score of 45-60 is considered adequate depth (a score of 100 is for a fully awake state and 0 for a completely silent brain). ENTROPY is a newer monitor which also works on the analysis of EEG

questions.text: A female was undergoing emergency thyroid surgery. She had risen in end tidal CO2. All of the following can be possible causes except: Anaphylaxis Malignant hyperthermia Thyroid storm Neuroleptic malignant syndrome Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2, 3, and 4 are correct Malignant hyperthermia, thyroid storm, and neuroleptic malignant syndrome are the three most important causes of increased CO2 production. In malignant hyperthermia, the rise in CO2 is disproportionate to the rise in temperature while in the other two conditions temperature and CO2 rises in proportion. There will not be any increase in CO2 in anaphylaxis

questions.text: Accurate guide for fluid infusion by dynamic parameters in modern-day clinical practice: CVP Pulse pressure variation Urine output Stroke volume variation Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 and 4 are correct Stroke volume variation (which is the variation in stroke volume during inspiration and expiration) and pulse pressure variation (which is the variation in pulse pressure during inspiration and expiration) are the dynamic parameters that are considered superior to static parameters like CVP for titrating the fluid. The variation > 10-15% indicates hypovolemia. Stroke volume variation is measured by echocardiography while pulse pressure variation can be calculated by invasive BP monitors.

Highyeild:

Other dynamic parameters which can be utilized for fluid titration are: Flow time across descending aorta – It is even considered better than stroke volume variation or pulse pressure variation Cardiac output Pulmonary artery occlusion pressure Urine output can be used to guide fluid in case of non-availability of monitors

questions.text: All are the Complication of the CVP line except: Airway injury Hemothorax Septicemia Pseudoaneurysm Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All are correct Complications of CVP line Carotid/ subclavian artery puncture by far is the most common immediate complication of CVP catheterization which can be easily managed by applying compression but if not detected and managed, then it may result in hemorrhage, pseudoaneurysm, stroke, or even death Trauma to the brachial plexus, carotid artery, phrenic nerve, and airway during insertion. Pneumothorax/hemothorax/pneumomediastinum/chylothorax (X-ray chest should be performed to check the position of the catheter and to exclude pneumothorax). Embolic complications like air embolism or thromboembolism Cardiac arrhythmias Cardiac perforation/cardiac tamponade (most fatal complication). Sepsis is the most common late complication

questions.text: Swan Ganz catheter measure: PCWP Cardiac output. Mixed venous O2 saturation Right atrial pressure Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All are correct Because of cost, technical feasibility, and complications ranging from minor arrhythmias ( most common complication, incidence around 30% ) to life-threatening like pulmonary artery rupture, severe arrhythmias, and death, pulmonary artery catheterization is reserved only for very major cases in severely compromised patients. Swan Ganz catheter is used for pulmonary artery catheterization. It can be utilized to: Measure all cardiac chambers pressure except the left ventricle. Calculating cardiac output- Cardiac output is calculated by using ice-cold saline (Thermodilution method). Measuring pulmonary artery occlusion pressure (PAOP) {formerly called as pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) Taking a sample for mixed venous blood (the pulmonary artery is considered the best site for a mixed venous blood sample) Titration of fluid infusion: PAOP is a better guide than CVP for fluid titration as it also measures preload to the left heart while CVP only measures preload to the right heart.

questions.text: Assertion- Pulse oximetry detects inaccurately the presence of abnormal hemoglobins Reason – Pulse oximeters only use 2 wavelengths.

options.label: A
options.text: Both assertion and reason are correct

options.label: B
options.text: Both assertion and reason are correct

options.label: C
options.text: Both assertion and reason are correct and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion

options.label: D
options.text: Both assertion and reason are correct and the reason is the incorrect explanation of the assertion

questions.correct_answer: A. Both assertion and reason are correct
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both assertion and reason are correct The pulse oximeters cannot detect abnormal hemoglobins because they use light with 2 wavelengths which are absorbed by deoxyhemoglobin and oxyhemoglobin. Co-oximeters and multiwavelength oximeters can measure other hemoglobin species like carboxyhemoglobin, methemoglobin, and Sulphhemoglobin because they are using light of 5 wavelengths which other than oxy and deoxyhemoglobin can be absorbed by these 3 species of hemoglobin also.
